prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given the broad line width, and to obtain maximal S/N ratio on the continuum, we select the broadest spw width. We will be able to observe the OH163um line in the lower sideband "for free", which is only a secondary science goal. The resolution in TDM is too coarse to allow for a precise line shape measurement, but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a moderate level.

Resolution is chosen to approximately match the lowest resolution attainable in the shortest wavelength lines. This is primarily a detection experiment. Based on the CO size, we expect the emission to be resolved over approcimately 2 beams. The LAS is a conservative limit, based on the observed full CO size.

The [CII] line strength was estimated based on the CO line and FIR continuum fluxes of the source by scaling off other galaxies of the same population at similar redshifts with [CII] detections (e.g., Cox et al. 2011; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014). This results in a predicted line peak flux of 183mJy, distributed over two beams. We assume the same line width as for the detected CO lines (468km/s FWHM). Given the significant overhead fraction, we integrate for ~10 minutes on source to obtain minimal uv coverage. This will allow us to obtain a precise line shape, and a high significance detection of the underlying continuum (50mJy distributed over ~2 beams). In a companion program (2015.1.00330.S), we ask for ~5x higher resolution [CII] observations of this source. Assuming that both proposals will be approved, we will use the data in this proposal as short spacings for that imaging project as well to maximize the science return.

Given the broad line width, and to obtain maximal S/N ratio on the continuum, we select the broadest spw width. The resolution in TDM is too coarse to allow for a precise line shape measurement, but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a moderate level.

Resolution is chosen to approximately match the lowest resolution attainable in the shortest wavelength lines. This is primarily a detection experiment. Based on the CO size, we expect the emission to be resolved over approcimately 2 beams. The LAS is a conservative limit, based on the observed full CO size.

The line strength was estimated based on typical [CII]/[NII] line ratios in nearby ultra-luminous infrared galaxies, which are expected to be similar in their physical properties to high-redshift dusty starbursts (e.g., Fischer et al. 2014). This results in a predicted line peak flux of 9mJy, distributed over two beams. We assume the same line width as for the detected CO lines (468km/s FWHM). Given the significant overhead fraction, we integrate for ~10 minutes on source to obtain minimal uv coverage. This will allow us to obtain an accurate line shape, and a high significance detection of the underlying continuum (32mJy distributed over ~2 beams).

Given the broad line width, and to obtain maximal S/N ratio on the continuum, we select the broadest spw width. The resolution in TDM is too coarse to allow for a precise line shape measurement, but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a moderate level.

Resolution is chosen to approximately match the lowest resolution attainable in the shortest wavelength lines. This is primarily a detection experiment. Based on the CO size, we expect the emission to be resolved over approcimately 2 beams. The LAS is a conservative limit, based on the observed full CO size.

The line strength was estimated based on typical [CII]/[NII] line ratios in nearby ultra-luminous infrared galaxies, which are expected to be similar in their physical properties to high-redshift dusty starbursts (e.g., Fischer et al. 2014). This results in a predicted line peak flux of 27mJy, distributed over two beams. We assume the same line width as for the detected CO lines (468km/s FWHM). Given the significant overhead fraction, we integrate for ~12 minutes on source to obtain minimal uv coverage. This will allow us to obtain an accurate line shape, and a high significance detection of the underlying continuum (90mJy distributed over ~2 beams).

Given the broad line width, and to obtain maximal S/N ratio on the continuum, we select the broadest spw width. The resolution in TDM is too coarse to allow for a precise line shape measurement, but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a moderate level.

Resolution is chosen to approximately match the lowest resolution attainable in the shortest wavelength lines. This is primarily a detection experiment. Based on the CO size, we expect the emission to be resolved over approcimately 2 beams. The LAS is a conservative limit, based on the observed full CO size.

The line strength was estimated based on typical [CII]/[OI] line ratios in nearby ultra-luminous infrared galaxies, which are expected to be similar in their physical properties to high-redshift dusty starbursts (e.g., Fischer et al. 2014). This results in a predicted line peak flux of 16mJy, distributed over two beams. We assume the same line width as for the detected CO lines (468km/s). Given the significant overhead fraction, we integrate for ~10 minutes on source to obtain minimal uv coverage. This will allow us to obtain an accurate line shape, and a high significance detection of the underlying continuum (70mJy distributed over ~2 beams).

Given the broad line width, and to obtain maximal S/N ratio on the continuum, we select the broadest spw width. The central spw will cover the full line, but we place spws adjacent on either side to cover potential broad line wings. The resolution in TDM is too coarse to allow for a precise line shape measurement, but we bin spectrally by a factor of 16 to keep data rates at a moderate level. We place a second spw in TDM mode on the line center to independently check the calibration accuracy at these high frequencies in the new band 10.

Resolution is chosen to approximately match the lowest resolution attainable in the shortest wavelength lines. This is primarily a detection experiment. Based on the CO size, we expect the emission to be resolved over approcimately 2-2.5 beams. The LAS is a conservative limit, based on the observed full CO size.

The line strength was estimated based on typical [CII]/[OIII] line ratios in nearby ultra-luminous infrared galaxies, which are expected to be similar in their physical properties to high-redshift dusty starbursts (e.g., Fischer et al. 2014). This results in a predicted line peak flux of 60mJy, distributed over two beams. We assume the same line width as for the detected CO lines (468km/s FWHM). We aim to achieve a S/N ratio of 7.5, to achieve a >5 sigma detection even if the line ratio is somewhat lower than typical. This will allow us to also obtain a high significance detection of the underlying continuum (75mJy distributed over ~2 beams).

Given the broad line width, and to obtain maximal S/N ratio on the continuum, we select the broadest spw width. The central spw will cover the full line, but we place spws adjacent on either side to cover potential broad line wings. The resolution in TDM is too coarse to allow for a precise line shape measurement, but we bin spectrally by a factor of 16 to keep data rates at a moderate level. We place a second spw in TDM mode on the line center to independently check the calibration accuracy at these high frequencies in the new band 10.

Resolution is chosen to approximately match the lowest resolution attainable in the shortest wavelength lines. This is primarily a detection experiment. Based on the CO size, we expect the emission to be resolved over approcimately 2-2.5 beams. The LAS is a conservative limit, based on the observed full CO size.

The line strength was estimated based on typical [CII]/[NIII] line ratios in nearby ultra-luminous infrared galaxies, which are expected to be similar in their physical properties to high-redshift dusty starbursts (e.g., Fischer et al. 2014). This results in a predicted line peak flux of 60mJy, distributed over two beams. We assume the same line width as for the detected CO lines (468km/s FWHM). We aim to achieve a S/N ratio of 5 over the line FWHM, to achieve solid detection. This will allow us to also obtain a high significance detection of the underlying continuum (120mJy distributed over ~2 beams).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Studies of the interstellar medium (ISM) at high redshift have progressed tremendously in the past years, but studies of the physical properties based on a suite of fine structure lines (which are critical for studying the earliest cosmic epochs, where CO is faint due to decreasing metallicity) are still in their beginning stages. We here propose an in-depth study of the ISM based on six CNO fine structure lines in a massive starburst galaxy at redshift 5.2 (where all lines fall into a "sweet spot" in the atmosphere), allowing us to push these studies back to the first billion years of cosmic time. This will allow us to measure the fraction of [CII] emission that originated from the neutral vs. ionized medium, the density of both the neutral and ionized medium, the effective temperature in HII regions associated with star-forming clouds, and the O/N abundance ratio. This study will detect fine structure lines up to rest-frame wavelengths of 52 micron in one of the most distant starburst galaxies known, making it an ideal demonstration case for the new ALMA band-10 receivers.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Astrophysics and Space Astronomy, Colorado at Boulder, Univ of
Research Division, Astrophysical Institute of Canarias
Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine
